narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Critical reading and thinking, deep understanding of Capital and the tenets of Marxism, better insights into the mechanisms of the capital mode of production
An ability to evaluate and consider a new way of looking at the economy and society.
I gained a deeper understanding of Capital by Karl Marx by reading it in full. I gained some appreciation for how a word can transform in history and in a specific work.

I learned a lot about Marx's depiction of the Capitalist system. In Class we discussed Marx's main critiques of the capitalist system, how his depiction of capitalism can be compared against our modern world, the influence of capitalism in non-economic spheres of life and much more. I developed the skill for conducting analysis of a philosophical text in spheres beyond that of the philosophical argument itself. We discussed a lot about the literary and historical value of Marx's Das Kapital text and these discussions taught me a lot.

Deep insight into Marx's Capital - contemporary and literal interpretations. Just one book, but it was a fantastic journey into the depths of Marxian thought, from sociology to history to economics. A truly superb exploration of the theoretical foundations of 'Marxism' and challenging the preconceived notions about Capital. We were apparently the "first group of undergraduates in 50 years who have critically read Vol. 1 like this.'   My way of thinking has been fundamentally changed - workers of the world, unite!
Everything
We read Karl Marx's Capital in great depth.

A close reading of Karl Marx's capital. The book starts with an explanation of what commodity is and how they are traded, to how they are made and how labor is exploited under capitalism. The book is a very thorough analysis of how capitalism works, the historical tendencies of capitalism towards subsumption and centralization, and a graphic illustration of the abuse and exploitation of workers under this system. It is the ultimate horror story. The colloquium once a week was also a great overview of present-day Marxist scholarship and how current thinkers interact with a text that, while almost two centuries old, remains as prescient as ever.
I learned a ton about Marx's Capital, as well about how to read a text like this.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This is an amazing course for everyone who is interested in marxism or wants to expand their understanding of capitalism. It is incredibly well-taught, challenging but not overwhelming, and has fostered some of the most intellectually fulfilling conversations of my Yale career so far.

Focus on the primary text was a plus.  Student engagement was generally pretty high - Prof North encouraged this.  On the to be improved side, Capital could have benefited from some readings that were a little more critical.  Alternatively, one of the guest speakers could have been chosen from a list of prominent critics.

The strengths of this class this semester were definitely Prof North, the TA's Vanessa and Leana, and the CT scan assignments which we were responsible for on a weekly basis.  Prof North was spectacular in his presentation of the context of the class. He also always created a welcoming environment in the seminar where many discussions were had. The TA's Vanessa and Leana also contributed to the success of the class. Vanessa is very knowledgeable of Marx's texts and the insights she provided in class improved my understanding of the philosophical content of the text. Leana on the other hand allowed me to perceive the connections between the philosophical content of the text and the audio-visual arts (in addition to literature). Finally, the CT scan assignments which we were responsible for on a weekly basis forced me to engage with the text in more ways than I would have otherwise.

Strengths - Paul North's teaching is fantastic, so were the CT scans (and Vanessa's comments). The colloquium was well organized and educational. Essays were fun and thought-provoking. Great discussion.
Weaknesses - The presentations could be more organized, and the class-notes/readings could be more structured.
Lectures were almost too long
The course was wonderful, Professor North and the TAs were extremely smart, interesting, and kind, and helped make the difficult material more approachable.

Paul North is a fantastic professor who explains the ideas of the text in a thoughtful and thought-provoking manner. The other biggest strength of this course is that it is completely devoted to Marx's Capital, which is something you are unlikely to find anywhere else in the institutional neoliberal course curriculum of Yale University. It is a place where students can feel comfortable discussing radical leftist ideas (or challenging those ideas, if they choose). The two hour seminar format could be difficult to sit through at times, and the ending of Capital felt a bit rushed, but overall one of the best classes I've taken here.
The lecture series was a huge strength!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Mandatory video and audio - no muting, was a wise requirement.  Breakout groups were helpful. Professor might consider cold calling.
Breakout rooms were useful and zoom colloquium was very well organized!
I appreciated that the course encouraged students to keep cameras and microphones on, and that it offered a five minute break in the middle.
Seminar format worked quite well over zoom, everyone got to talk and had interesting discussions. Breakout rooms also worked well to give more people the chance to talk through the material.
I think this course did virtual quite well.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, anyone who wants to learn more about Marx(ism) should take it, no questions asked!
Yes.  Great course. Exposure to ideas that are not conventional. Obtain an understanding of an important work in modern society.
I would recommend this course to another student. I think the subject matter that the course treats is important, and I think the course allows for a thorough exploration of this.
I would definitely recommend this class to another student

Yes! If you are a student of Germanic Study, Philosophy, or Humanities - YES
If you have even a tinge of interest in Marx, Socialism or Communism - YES
If you are ready and willing to challenge yourself, to read one complex book with a fine toothcomb, and to revolutionize your way of thinking - Don't think twice.
Absolutely, an eye-opening class
I would absolutely recommend this course to another student, it was extremely interesting and important, and changed how I view the world.

Absolutely. Marx's Capital is a foundational text for understanding the system we live in, and I think the world would be much better off if everyone had to read it. I know for me the book was absolutely eye-opening and completely altered my perception of our society.
Absolutely.
